moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6:
Lasker: Steinitz's well-known defense.

Steinitz: The revival of this defense met with much opposition, but I have seen nothing as yet to vitiate the equalizing effect, which, in my opinion, it possess.
moves.4. d4 Bd7 5. Nc3 Nge7: Steinitz: An important key move to this defense which I first adopted in my match against Gunsberg.
moves.6. Bc4: Lasker: Apparently loss of time, but the good position of that bishop seems ample compensation
moves.6... Nxd4 7. Nxd4 exd4 8. Qxd4 Nc6 9. Qe: Steinitz: Of doubtful merit. 11...Be7 at once was preferable.
moves.12. h4: Lasker: 12.Be3 was strong enough in this position. However, the text move embarrasses Black's development of pieces.
Lasker: If 16...Bxh4 17.Qg4, and now Black cannot play 17...Qc8, as 18.Rxh4 would follow, and he cannot stir the bishop on account of 18.Rxh7.

Steinitz: If 16...Bxh4 17.Qg4 Be7 18.Rxh7, and should win.
moves.17. Ne2 Rf7: Steinitz: Again Black would expose himself to great danger by 17...Bxh4 18.Qg4, followed soon by Qh5.
moves.18. h5: Lasker: It would have been risky to leave the pawn on its fourth, and to proceed with an attack by means of 18.Kb1. It might, however, have been promising enough.
moves.18... Nf4 19. Bxf4 exf4 20. Qf3: Steinitz: Obviously if 20.Nxf4 Rxf4, and the queen dare not retake.
moves.29... Re7e5 30. g3: Steinitz: A masterly coup, which relieves his position on the kingside, no matter what Black reply.
moves.30... Rg5: Lasker: Of course if 30...fxg3 31.f4, and Black would do best to sacrifice the exchange.
moves.34. exd5 cxd5: Steinitz: 34...Rxd5 is preferable, leading to a natural draw position, with which I should have been content under the circumstances.
moves.35. Nb3 Re6 36. Rhf1 Rge5 37. Nc1: Lasker: This forces the win of a pawn.
moves.37... Bc7 38. Nd3 Rg5 39. Nb4 Ree5 40. R: Lasker: A very fine move, which nearly would have turned the tables.
moves.41. Rxf4+ Kg8 42. Nd3: Steinitz: Much inferior to 42.Nc2, which wins easily.
moves.42... Re2 43. Rd1 Be3 44. Rb4 b6 45. Ra4:
Steinitz: This gives Black a chance for a counter-attack, which I believe should have equalized the game
at least.
moves.46... d4 47. c4: Lasker: White has nothing better as 47.cxd4 would be neutralized with 47...Rb5.
moves.47... Bd2 48. b5 Bc3 49. Rg1 Rd2:
Lasker: Black intends to sacrifice his exchange and very nearly succeeds in scoring the game thereby.  As will be seen by the subsequent play, Black excels in detecting means of attack, which could only be met by a series of difficult and forced moves on the part of his antagonist.

Steinitz: Ill-judged. 49...Kf7 seems better, with the following probable continuation: 50.f4 Rc5 51.Nxc5 bxc5, with better drawing chances.
moves.51. Rxg4 Rxd3 52. c5: Steinitz: Black cannot recover from the effects of this splendid move.
moves.52... Re3: Steinitz: If 52...Rd1+ 53.Kc2 Rd2+ 54.Kb3 (54.Kb1 drives by 54...d3) 54... bxc5 55.Kc4, and wins.

gameName: World Championship Match, Game 1, New York
opening: Ruy Lopez (C62), old Steinitz defence, Nimzovich attack
